title: Bwin Deal Marks Big Win for U.S.-Style Activism in Europe
text:
Print Last year, activist Jason Ader launched a fight to shake up the board of gaming company Bwin.party and compared the company’s management slide to the strength of its Gibraltar neighbor 888 Holdings PLC. 
Today, Mr. Ader is cheering as 888 inked a deal to buy Bwin for $1.4 billion in cash and stock. 
“It’s always been on my radar as the management team that would probably run the bwin assets better than anybody else,” Mr. Ader said in an interview Friday. 
Mr. Ader’s success in first getting a representative on the board of bwin and now helping push a deal with 888 marks a big win for American-style activism in Europe, where few have tread so far despite much talk. There have been European activists who have been forced changes, but the U.S. style of pushing board changes publicly have been few and far between. 
“I’ll take credit for being the most successful American activist in Europe,” Mr. Ader says today, adding he’d be open to trying more. 
After several months of fighting last summer, in which Mr. Ader was critical of bwin’s management and performance, the sides settled on the eve of the vote to give Daniel Silvers, the president of his fund SpringOwl Asset Management, a seat at the board. 
Mr. Ader says he developed a strong relationship with bwin chairman Philip Yea and urged 888 to get a seat at the table when bwin was running a sales process. 
Going forward, Mr. Ader says he’ll look to acquire as much 888 stock as he can in the deal and let other shareholders take cash as he believes the combined company will have a chance to challenge online-gaming giant Amaya. More from The Wall Street Journal
